questions.text: A 30-year-old patient reports that rubbing the injured area provides him temporary relief from pain. According to the gate-control theory of pain, what is the primary mechanism behind this relief?

choices.text: Increased activation of nociceptive C fibers to reduce pain perception
Simultaneous activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors
Aα and Aβ fibers inhibit pain signals from C fibers in the ventral horn of spinal cord
Inhibition of Aa and Aß fibers reduces the transmission of pain signals to the brain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Simultaneous activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors

 

Explanation:

Rubbing or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to the injury. This is due to simultaneous activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors thereby reducing pain by affecting dorsal horn neuron responsiveness. This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation.

 

Gate control theory: Developed By Patrick David Wall and Ronald Melzack

  • It suggests that pain perception is influenced by the interaction of different nerve fibers in the spinal cord.
  • Large-diameter Aα and Aβ fibers inhibit pain signals from C fibers in the dorsal horn of spinal cord by activating inhibitory interneurons, effectively "closing the gate". (Option C, D ruled out)
  • When small-diameter fibers are more active, they "open the gate," allowing pain signals to reach the brain.

Influencing Factors:

  • Psychological factors, including cognitive and emotional states affect gate control.
  • Depression can keep the gate open more often, increasing pain perception
  • Unhealthy lifestyles can also result in open gates.

Application:

  • According to the gate-control theory, electrical stimulation of large nerve fibers should inhibit pain induced by C fibers alone.
  • Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) uses electrodes to activate Aa and Aß fibers near the injury, thereby using the gate-control mechanism for pain relief.
  • Acupuncture.

 

Analgesic systems:

Target/Mechanism

Description

Opioids
 
  • Reduce pain by acting at multiple levels of the nervous system.
  • They act at Spinal Cord, Dorsal Root Ganglia, Periaqueductal Grey (PAG)
  • Opioids inhibit pain transmission by activating receptors, reducing calcium influx, and promoting inhibitory neurotransmitter release.

TRPV1 Receptors

Targeted by capsaicin, involved in sensing heat and inflammatory pain; can deplete substance P to reduce pain.

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels
  • Blocked by local anesthetics like lidocaine and mexiletine, crucial for action potential generation in nociceptors.
  • The Nav1.8 subtype is a target for chronic pain management.

Voltage-Gated Calcium Channels

Blocked by drugs like ziconotide, gabapentin, and topiramate, reducing neurotransmitter release in pain pathways.

NMDA Receptors

Antagonists co-administered with opioids to prevent tolerance development, prolonging opioid effectiveness.

Increased activation of nociceptive C fibres to reduce pain perception (Option A) is not correct as increased activation of nociceptive C fibres would actually enhance pain perception, not reduce it.

questions.text: Action potentials in an afferent fiber from a mechanoreceptor of a single sensory unit is recorded in response to pressure stimulus. Which of the following principle is shown here:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Frequency coding principle

 

Explanation:

The principle shown here is the Frequency Coding Principle.

 

  • The Frequency Coding Principle states that the intensity of a stimulus is encoded by the frequency of action potentials generated in the afferent fibers.
  • As pressure increases, the firing rate of action potentials in the mechanoreceptor increases, conveying information about the strength of the stimulus
  • Action potentials in an afferent fiber from a mechanoreceptor of a single sensory unit increase in frequency as branches of the afferent neuron are stimulated by pressure of increasing magnitude.


 

Labelled Line Principle (Option A) refers to the idea that specific pathways in the nervous system convey specific types of sensory information.

 

Weber-Fechner Law (Option B) relates to the perception of changes in stimulus intensity and the relationship between the actual change and perceived change.

 

Concept of Specific Nerve Energy (Option D) suggests that each type of sensory nerve fiber is dedicated to a specific type of sensory information, regardless of how it is activated.

questions.text: The receptive fields (shown as red areas on fingertips) and firing rate of four different types of mechanoreceptors supplied by FA1, FA2, SA1 and SA2 afferent are shown here. The figure marked with B is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Merkel’s disc

 

Explanation:

The figure marked with B represents Merkel's disc

The human hand contains four types of mechanoreceptors that work together to sense contact with objects:

  • Merkel cells and Ruffini endings: Activate for steady pressure.
  • Meissner and Pacinian corpuscles: Activate for tingling and vibratory sensations.

 

Location of a stimulus is encoded by spatial distribution of the population of receptors activated. A receptor fires only when the skin close to its sensory terminals is touched. The receptive fields of mechanoreceptors (shown as red areas on fingertips) differ in size and response to touch.

 

  • Merkel cells and Meissner corpuscles provide the most precise localization as they have the smallest receptive fields and are most sensitive to pressure applied by a small probe.

 

Stimulus intensity is signaled by firing rates of individual receptors; duration of stimulus is signaled by time course of firing. The spike trains indicate action potentials elicited by pressure from a small probe at the center of each receptive field.

 

  • Meissner and Pacinian corpuscles adapt rapidly, the others adapt slowly

 

Accommodation: Refers to a gradual increase in threshold caused by prolonged slowly rising sub-threshold nerve depolarization, resulting from the inactivation of sodium channels.

 

Adaptation: If a supra-threshold stimulus persists unchanged for several minutes without a change in position or amplitude, the neural response diminishes and sensation is lost, a condition called receptor adaptation.

questions.text: A patient with paraplegia uses thigh stimulation to manage bladder and bowel control, leading to involuntary evacuation. Which reflex is being utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mass reflex

 

Explanation:

Mass reflex is due to excessive activity in the spinal cord causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. Mass reflex can sometimes be used to give patients with paraplegia a degree of bladder and bowel control. They can be trained to initiate urination and defecation by stroking or pinching their thighs, thus producing an intentional mass reflex.
 

Reflex

Description

Key Points

Mass Reflex

Excessive activity in the spinal cord causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. (Option B)
  • Results from activation of large numbers of reverberating circuits in the cord at once.
  • Can last for minutes
  • Stimulus: strong pain stimulus or excessive filling of a viscus (e.g., bladder or gut).
  • Effects: Strong flexor spasm in skeletal muscles, evacuation of colon and bladder, increased arterial pressure, profuse sweating.

Righting Reflex

Reflex involving uncoordinated movements to raise the body to a standing position when laid on the side. (Option A ruled out)
  • Demonstrates complex reflexes associated with posture integrated in the spinal cord.
  • Animals with a healed transected thoracic cord can right itself from lying position and even walk using both forelimbs and hindlimbs.
  • Consists of:
    • Labyrinthine Righting Reflex,
    • Neck Righting Reflex,
    • Body Righting Reflex,
    • Limb Righting Reflex,
    • Optical Righting Reflex.

Hopping Reflex

Short steps taken by an individual to balance the body when pushed laterally. (Option C ruled out)
  • Helps maintain balance and stability after lateral push.
  • Impaired following decortication.
  • Indicates that motor cortex is the center for integration of hopping reactions.

Placing Reflex

Placing feet firmly on the ground to attain and maintain a new stable position after lateral push. (Option D ruled out)
  • Ensures stability after the initial balance provided by the hopping reaction.
  • Impaired following decortication.
  • Indicates that motor cortex is the center for integration of placing reactions.

questions.text:
A 20 years old man is brought to the emergency room after stepping on a nail while walking barefoot. Upon examination, the following observations are made, Which of the following best describes the reflex pathways involved in this scenario?


	Right foot: Immediately withdraws upon being touched.
	Left foot: Planted firmly on the ground.

choices.text:
Monosynaptic stretch reflex
			
			
			Polysynaptic crossed extensor reflex

Polysynaptic flexor reflex
			
			
			Monosynaptic stretch reflex

Polysynaptic flexor reflex
			
			
			Polysynaptic crossed extensor reflex

Polysynaptic flexor reflex
			
			
			Monosynaptic stretch reflex

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right - Polysynaptic flexor reflex; Left - Polysynaptic crossed extensor reflex.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Right foot withdrawal: Stepping on a nail triggers the withdrawal reflex, also known as the flexor reflex, which is polysynaptic.
  • Left foot response: The withdrawal reflex also involves a crossed extensor reflex which is polysynaptic reflex.

 

Reflex

Withdrawal Reflex

Flexor Reflex

Crossed Extensor Reflex

Description

A protective reflex that causes withdrawal of a limb or body part from a stimulus.

A withdrawal reflex in which the primary response is flexion of a limb.

A component of the withdrawal reflex that occurs in the opposite limb.

Receptor

Nociceptors (e.g., pain receptors)

Nociceptors

Nociceptors in the contralateral limb are indirectly activated.

Afferent Fiber

Group III and IV (pain) and Group II (pressure)

Group III and IV (pain) and Group II (pressure)

Signals are relayed from the stimulated side.

Synapses

Polysynaptic (Options A, D ruled out)

Polysynaptic

Polysynaptic (Option B ruledout)

Efferent Fiber

α-motor neurons to flexors

α-motor neurons to flexors

α-motor neurons to extensors

Response

Flexion of ipsilateral limb or body part to move it away from the stimulus.

Contraction of flexor muscles and relaxation of extensor muscles in the stimulated limb.

Extension of the contralateral limb.

Clinical Significance

It is a protective mechanism, absence or weakness of this can indicate spinal cord injury or dysfunction.

Part of the withdrawal reflex and essential for rapid response to painful stimuli.

Provides support and balance during withdrawal of the opposite limb.

questions.text: A 30 years old woman presents with a history of multiple sclerosis. Upon examination, she exhibits ankle clonus when the examiner briskly dorsiflexes her foot. What is the most likely cause of clonus in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyperactive muscle spindles

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of multiple sclerosis and the presence of ankle clonus strongly suggest damage to the descending motor pathways.
  • This damage leads to hyperactive muscle spindles and, consequently, clonus.
  • Clonus is characterized by rhythmic muscle contractions in response to sustained stretch.

CLONUS

Definition

Regular, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of a muscle subjected to sudden, maintained stretch

Cause

Increased γ-motor neuron activity leading to hypersensitive muscle spindles

Mechanism

Hypersensitivity to stretch triggers rhythmic contractions

Common Sites

Ankle clonus initiated by brisk, maintained dorsiflexion of the foot, leading to rhythmic plantar flexion

Associated Conditions
  • Damage to descending motor pathways
  • Traumatic brain injury
  • Brain tumors
  • Strokes
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Spinal cord injury

Renshaw Cells
  • Inhibitory interneurons receiving excitatory input from α-motor neurons
  • Damage leads to loss of inhibitory control, contributing to clonus

Reflexes Involved
  • Stretch reflex
  • Inverse stretch reflex
  • Interplay in hypersensitive muscle spindles contributes to clonus

 

Increased GABAergic activity (Option B) in the spinal cord would actually reduce clonus as GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. 

 

Enhanced Golgi tendon organ activation (Option D): Golgi tendon organs (GTOs) are involved in the inverse stretch reflex, which causes muscle relaxation in response to increased tension.

questions.text: A 35 year old weightlifter is lifting a heavier weight than usual and feels a sudden, intense muscle contraction in his biceps, the muscle suddenly relaxes, preventing a potential muscle tear. Which reflex is responsible for this protective muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inverse stretch reflex

 

Explanation:

  • Inverse Stretch Reflex is activated when there is excessive tension in a muscle, as detected by the Golgi tendon organ (GTO).
  • When the tension becomes too high, the GTO sends signals to the spinal cord, which in turn inhibits the alpha motor neurons innervating the same muscle, leading to muscle relaxation.

Feature

Stretch Reflex (Option C ruled out)

Inverse Stretch Reflex

Receptor

Muscle Spindle

Golgi Tendon Organ

Stimulus

Muscle Stretch

Muscle Tension

Response

Muscle Contraction

Muscle Relaxation

Function

Maintain Muscle Length, Posture

Protect from Excessive Force

Type of Reflex

Monosynaptic

Polysynaptic



Withdrawal Reflex (Option B) is a protective mechanism that causes a body part to automatically move away from a source of pain or discomfort. 

 

Crossed extensor reflex (Option D) causes the opposite limb to extend when a withdrawal reflex is initiated in one limb.

questions.text: A 45 year old weightlifter is attempting a deadlift. As he lifts the weight, he feels a sudden, intense pain in his hamstring muscle and immediately drops the weight. What is the role of the Golgi tendon organ in this scenario?

choices.text: To prevent muscle damage by causing reflex inhibition of the contracting muscle.
To increase the sensitivity of muscle spindles
To send information about muscle length to the brain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To prevent muscle damage by causing reflex inhibition of the contracting muscle.

 

Explanation:

The Golgi tendon organ, when activated by excessive muscle tension, triggers a protective reflex that inhibits the contracting muscle, preventing tendon rupture or muscle tearing.

 

Golgi tendon organ

Location and Structure
  • Muscle tendons.
  • Encapsulated sensory receptors.
  • Around 10-15 muscle fibers are connected.

Stimulus
  • Tension in the muscle, as reflected by tension in the tendon.
  • Sudden, strong muscle contractions increase tension in the tendon

Function
  • Control and prevent excessive muscle tension.
  • Operates as a negative feedback system.

Reflex Pathway
  • When stimulated, signals are transmitted to the spinal cord, triggering the inverse stretch reflex (also called autogenic inhibition).
  • The signal activates an inhibitory interneuron in the spinal cord.
  • The interneuron inhibits the anterior motor neuron of the respective muscle, causing relaxation, this is a bisynaptic pathway.
  • This protects the muscle and tendon from excessive tension that might cause tearing.

Afferent Fiber

Golgi tendon organ to the spinal cord via large, fast-conducting type Ib nerve fibers.

Vs Muscle spindle

Muscle spindle - muscle length. (Option D ruled out)

Goldi tendon organ - muscle tension.

 

To directly cause muscle contraction (Option A): Alpha motor neurons are responsible for muscle contraction 

To increase the sensitivity of muscle spindles (Option C): Gamma motor neurons are responsible for regulating the sensitivity of muscle spindles

questions.text: A 28 year old man presents with experience of prolonged episodes of tingling and numbness in his right arm. A reflex hammer test on the patient's patellar tendon noted a weaker than normal knee-jerk reflex and decision to use the Jendrassik maneuver to enhance the reflex response was taken. Which of the following is directly activated by the Jendrassik maneuver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) γ-motor neuron

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Jendrassik maneuver, which can involve actions such as clenching the teeth or pulling on the hands, activates γ-motor neurons.
  • γ-motor neurons, also called gamma efferent fibers, innervate intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Muscle contraction

Feature

Direct

Indirect

Definition

Occurs when α-motor neurons are directly stimulated.

Occurs when the muscle spindle is activated, leading to the activation of α-motor neurons via the stretch reflex pathway.

Pathway

Monosynaptic

Monosynaptic

Purpose

Voluntary movements

Involuntary, provides damping to smooth muscle contractions.

Example

Picking up an object.

Maintaining posture, reacting to unexpected changes in load on a muscle (e.g., catching a ball).

 

Jendrassik Maneuver:

  • Clinical technique used to enhance the sensitivity of the stretch reflex (and thus, the response of the muscle spindle).
  • The maneuver involves the patient performing an isometric contraction in a muscle group distant from the one being tested.
    • Clenching the teeth
    • Locking the fingers and pulling the hands apart
    • Squeezing the knees together.
  • The maneuver is thought to increase γ-motor neuron activity, making the muscle spindles more sensitive to stretch.

 

Alpha-Gamma Coactivation:

  • On voluntary muscle contraction, the brain often signals both α- and γ-motor neurons simultaneously. This is known as alpha-gamma coactivation.
  • Activating γ-motor neurons causes intrafusal fibers to contract, maintaining tension in the spindle ensuring that spindle remains sensitive to stretch even during voluntary contractions.
  • Example: When catching a ball, alpha-gamma coactivation keeps the muscle spindles responsive and allows for rapid adjustments to maintain grip and arm position as the weight of the ball impacts the hand.

 

α-motor neuron (Option A): While the knee-jerk reflex does involve the activation of α-motor neurons to cause the quadriceps muscle to contract, the Jendrassik maneuver does not directly activate these neurons. 

 

Golgi tendon organ (Option C): the sensitivity of the Golgi tendon organ is not directly affected by the Jendrassik maneuver. 

 

Extrafusal muscle fibers (Option D) are not directly activated by the Jendrassik maneuver.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the sequence of events in the stretch reflex pathway?

choices.text: Spinal cord → Muscle spindle → α-motor neuron → Muscle contraction
Muscle spindle → Spinal cord → α-motor neuron → Muscle contraction
Spinal cord→ α-motor neuron →Muscle spindle →Muscle contraction
Muscle spindle →α-motor neuron → Spinal cord → Muscle contraction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle spindle → Spinal cord → α-motor neuron → Muscle contraction

 

Explanation:

 

Stretch reflex pathway: Regulates muscle length and contributes to postural control. It is initiated by the stretching of muscle, which activates specialised sensory receptors.

 

  • Muscle Spindles: 
    • Consists of intrafusal muscle fibers (nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers),
    • Sensory nerve endings (group Ia and II afferent fibers), and
    • Gamma motor neuron endings
  • Afferent Limb:
    • When a muscle is stretched, the muscle spindles are also stretched, stimulating the sensory endings.
    • This stretch-induced stimulation generates receptor potentials that trigger action potentials in the afferent fibers.
  • Integration Center:
    • The Ia afferent fibers, have a large diameter and, conduct action potentials, transmit signals to the spinal cord through the dorsal roots.
    • Within the spinal cord, these fibers form direct (monosynaptic) connections with alpha motor neurons located in the anterior horn.
  • Efferent Limb:
    • The activated alpha motor neurons send signals through axons, which exit the spinal cord and travel to the extrafusal muscle fibers.
  • Effector:
    • The arrival of action potentials at the neuromuscular junctions causes the release of acetylcholine, initiating muscle fiber contraction.
    • This counteracts the initial stretch by shortening the muscle, thus restoring its original length.

questions.text: A 45 year old man presents with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty maintaining balance. Upon examination, the physician notices that the patient has diminished reflexes. Which of the following nerve fibers is responsible for transmitting information about the velocity and length of muscle stretch from the muscle spindle to the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type Ia fibers

 

Explanation:

  • Type Ia fibers are large, rapidly conducting sensory fibers that originate from the central portion of both nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers within the muscle spindle.
  • These fibers are responsible for transmitting information about the velocity and length of muscle stretch to the spinal cord.

 

 

Afferent (Sensory)

Efferent (Motor)

Fiber Type

Type Ia fibers

Type II fibers

Aγ fibers

γ-dynamic (γ-d) fibers

γ-static (γ-s) fibers

Description

Large, rapidly conducting fibers

Smaller sensory fibers that innervate nuclear chain fibers.

Smaller motor fibers that innervate the intrafusal fibers.

Excite nuclear bag intrafusal fibers.

Excite nuclear chain intrafusal fibers.

Function

Transmit information about velocity and length of muscle stretch.

Transmit information about static length of the muscle.

(Option B ruled out)

Adjusts sensitivity of the muscle spindle.

(Option C ruled out)

Enhance the dynamic response (sensitivity to the velocity of muscle stretch).

Enhance the static response (sensitivity to steady-state muscle length).

Origin

Annulospiral (primary) endings wrapped around the center of dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

Secondary endings located adjacent to the centers of static nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers.

Gamma motor neurons in the anterior horns of the spinal cord.


 		    

 

Afferent and Efferent Fibres" data-author="NA" data-hash="7851" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="367" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/fSsUUWJu7ODggEJfqSwc1744010595.png" width="500" />

Afferent Connections of the Muscle Spindle Efferent Connections of the Muscle Spindle

 

Type Ib fibers (Option A) are large and rapidly conducting fibers, that originate from the Golgi tendon organs and transmit information about muscle tension, not muscle length.

questions.text: A 32 years old man came for an evaluation of muscle spasms and difficulty with fine motor tasks. Upon examination, the patient has hyperactive deep tendon reflexes and experiences a persistent tremor during voluntary movements. Which of the following types of intrafusal muscle fibers, would most likely cause this hyperactive deep tendon reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dynamic nuclear bag fibers

 

Explanation:

  • Dynamic nuclear bag fibers are highly sensitive to the velocity of muscle stretch.
  • When a muscle is stretched rapidly, these fibers fire strongly, leading to a robust activation of the stretch reflex, which causes exaggerated stretch reflexes.

 

Types of intrafusal fibers

Nuclear Bag Fiber
  • Respond to changes in muscle length (stretch).
  • Two subtypes: dynamic and static.

Dynamic Nuclear Bag Fiber

Detects real-time shortening/lengthening of a muscle (i.e., the velocity).

Static Nuclear Bag Fiber

Detects sustained/maintained length of a muscle but plays no role in detecting velocity. (Option B ruled out)

Nuclear Chain Fiber
  • Thinner and shorter than nuclear bag fibers and lack a definite bag.
  • Static response of the muscle spindle, providing information about the steady-state muscle length. (Option C ruled out)

 

Extrafusal fibers (Option D) are regular contractile fibers of skeletal muscle responsible for generating force and movement. They are not a part of the muscle spindle and do not directly contribute to the stretch reflex.

questions.text: The muscle spindle is primarily involved in detecting changes in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle length

 

Explanation:

  • Muscle spindles are sensory receptors found within skeletal muscle.
  • The function of a muscle spindle is to detect changes in muscle length, also called stretch.

 

Muscle spindle receptor:

Muscle Spindle Receptor

Location

Encapsulated sensory receptors in skeletal muscle, attached to tendons.

Components

Each spindle contains 3 to 12 intrafusal muscle fibers.

Sensory Endings

Stimulated by stretching.

Types of Sensory Endings

Primary Afferent Endings (Annulospiral): Sensitive to velocity of muscle length change (dynamic response).

Secondary Afferent Endings (Flower-Spray): Sensitive to steady-state muscle length (static response).

Types of Gamma Motor Neurons

Gamma-Dynamic (γ-d): Excites nuclear bag intrafusal fibers. Gamma-Static (γ-s): Excites nuclear chain intrafusal fibers.

Functions

Regulating Muscle Length: Provides feedback to regulate muscle length. Damping: Smoothens muscle contractions and prevents jerkiness. Stabilizing Body Position: Maintains posture and balance by informing the spinal cord and motor centers about muscle length.

Higher Motor Control: Information is transmitted to the cerebellum and cerebral cortex.

 

Muscle Spindle Receptor" data-author="NA" data-hash="7857" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="307" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/lIwELzoimQh1yDiUZ2681744015307.png" width="500" />

Muscle Tension (Option A): Golgi tendon organs are the receptors responsible for detecting muscle tension.

 

Skin stretch (Option C) is detected by cutaneous mechanoreceptors, such as Ruffini Corpuscles.

 

Joint Pressure (Option D): Joint capsule receptors are responsible for detecting joint pressure.

questions.text: A 35 y/o presented after a car accident and complained of severe pain. They administered morphine, knowing it acts on the descending pain modulation system. Which of the following brain regions and neurotransmitters are correctly paired and activated by morphine?

choices.text: Periaqueductal grey (PAG) neurons - endorphins in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Periventricular nucleus neurons - norepinephrine in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Periaqueductal grey (PAG) neurons - directly release serotonin in the nucleus raphe magnus.
Periventricular nucleus neurons - enkephalins in the rostral ventromedial medulla.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Periaqueductal grey (PAG) neurons - endorphins in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

  • The periaqueductal grey (PAG) matter region in the midbrain plays a crucial role in the descending pain modulation pathway.
  • When stimulated by opioids like morphine, PAG neurons activate neurons in the brainstem, the nucleus raphe magnus (which releases serotonin) and the rostral ventromedial medulla (which releases norepinephrine).
  • These neurons project to the dorsal horn, where they release their respective neurotransmitters to inhibit the activity of pain-transmitting neurons.

Brain Region

Neurotransmitter Released

Site

Effect

Periaqueductal grey (PAG)

Endorphins

Dorsal horn of the spinal cord

Inhibits pain transmission by activating enkephalin-containing interneurons.

Nucleus raphe magnus

Activates neurons that release serotonin.

Rostral ventromedial medulla

Activates neurons that release norepinephrine.

Periventricular region (PV)

Endorphins

Raphe Magnus nucleus

Activates neurons that release serotonin.

(Option B and D ruled out)

 

Periventricular nucleus neurons - enkephalins in the rostral ventromedial medulla (Option C) is not true as PAG does not directly release serotonin; it activates serotonergic neurons in the nucleus raphe magnus.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the sensory perception abilities of different body parts in humans. She observes that some areas of the body can detect finer details and small differences in stimuli better than others. Which of the following statements best explains the reason behind the high sensitivity and discriminatory abilities in certain body areas?

choices.text: Small receptive fields and low receptor density.
Large receptive fields and high receptor density.
Small receptive fields and high receptor density.
Large receptive fields and low receptor density.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Small receptive fields, high receptor density.

 

Explanation:

Small receptive fields coupled with a high receptor density allow for precise localisation and detailed discrimination of sensory stimuli, making these areas highly sensitive.

 

Classification of Sensory Receptors

Function

Type

Specific Receptor

Mechanoreceptors

Detect mechanical compression or stretching of the receptor or adjacent tissues

Skin Tactile Sensibilities (epidermis and dermis)
  • Free nerve endings,
  • Expanded tip endings (Merkel's discs)
  • Spray endings,
  • Ruffini's endings,
  • Encapsulated endings (Meissner's corpuscles, Krause's corpuscles)
  • Hair end-organs

Deep Tissue Sensibilities
  • Free nerve endings,
  • Expanded tip endings,
  • Spray endings,
  • Ruffini's endings,
  • Encapsulated endings (Pacinian corpuscles),
  • Muscle endings (Muscle spindles, Golgi tendon receptors)

Hearing

Sound receptors of cochlea

Equilibrium

Vestibular receptors

Arterial Pressure

Baroreceptors of carotid sinuses and aorta

Thermoreceptors

Detect changes in temperature (cold or warmth)

Cold

Cold receptors

Warmth

Warm receptors

Nociceptors (pain receptors)

Detect physical or chemical damage in the tissue

Pain

Free nerve endings

Electromagnetic Receptors

Detect light on the retina of the eye

Vision
  • Rods
  • Cones

Chemoreceptors

Detect various chemical changes including taste, smell, blood oxygen levels, osmolality, and CO2 concentration

Taste

Receptors of taste buds

Smell

Receptors of olfactory epithelium

Arterial Oxygen

Receptors of aortic and carotid bodies

Osmolality

Neurons in or near supraoptic nuclei

Blood CO2

Receptors in/on the surface of the medulla, aortic and carotid bodies

Blood Glucose, Amino Acids, Fatty Acids

Receptors in hypothalamus

Receptive Field Sizes

Location

Receptive Field Size

Characteristics

Fingertips

Small

Fine two-point discrimination, high precision

Back

Large

Poorer two-point discrimination, low precision

Receptor Density

Area

Receptor Density

Sensitivity and Discrimination

Fingertips, Lips, Tongue

High

Greater sensitivity, fine detail discrimination

Back, Forearm

Low

Less sensitivity, coarse discrimination

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient develops a persistent burning pain in the left arm following a thalamic stroke. Which of the following statements about thalamic pain syndrome is false?

choices.text: Due to damage to the thalamus.
Can result from both ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes
Typically short-lived and resolves within a few months
Antidepressants and anticonvulsants are commonly used for treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Typically short-lived and resolves within a few months

 

Explanation:

Thalamic pain syndrome typically starts within the first six months post stroke, but can develop even after ten years. It is persistent and potentially life-long pain that does not resolve.

Definition

Thalamic pain syndrome or Dejerine Roussy syndrome or Central post-stroke pain is a rare central neuropathic pain syndrome that occurs after infarction of the ventro-posterolateral thalamus

Aetiology

Vascular lesions affecting the central somatosensory system, most commonly ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke (Option B ruled out)

Pathophysiology

Damage to the spinothalamic tract or thalamus disrupts sensory processing, leading to abnormal pain perception (Option A ruled out)

Epidemiology

Prevalence ranges from 8% to 46%

Onset

Typically within the first six months post-stroke, but can develop after ten years also

Symptoms
  • Sharp, burning and stabbing pain with hyperalgesia and allodynia;
  • Pain is described as pricking, aching, freezing, shooting, etc.

Diagnosis

Based on history, clinical examination, and imaging: CT/MRI to confirm stroke

Treatment

Pharmacological:

  1. Antidepressants,
  2. Anticonvulsants, (Option D ruled out)
  3. Opioids,
  4. NMDA receptor antagonists

Non-Pharmacological:

  1. Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS),
  2. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS),
  3. Deep brain stimulation (DBS)
  4. Motor cortex stimulation

Prognosis
  • Poor
  • Persistent and potentially life-long pain (Option C)

Complications
  • Reduces quality of life
  • Depression or anxiety
  • Sleep disturbance
  • Drug dependence
  • Poor social interactions
  • Increased suicide risk

questions.text: Which statement correctly explains the localization capability of the paleospinothalamic pathway for pain?

choices.text: The pathway allows precise localization of pain to specific points on the body
The pathway localizes pain only to major body parts, such as an arm or leg, due to its diffuse connectivity.
The pathway is responsible for localizing temperature changes in the body.
The pathway can localize pain to exact muscle groups involved in movement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The pathway localizes pain only to major body parts, such as an arm or leg, due to its diffuse connectivity.

 

Explanation:

Slow-chronic pain can usually be localized only to a major part of the body, such as one arm or leg, but not to a specific point on the arm or leg. This phenomenon is due to the multisynaptic, diffuse connectivity of the Paleo-Spinothalamic pathway, which is why patients have difficulty localizing the source in some chronic types of pain.

 

Paleo-Spinothalamic Pathway 

Aspect

Description

Fiber type

Type C fibers and some Aδ fibers

Function

Transmits slow-chronic pain from peripheral type C fibers and some type Aδ fibers

First Order Neurons

Enter spinal cord, terminate in laminae II and III of dorsal horns (Substantia gelatinosa), signals then pass to lamina V

Second Order Neurons
  • Cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord through the anterior commissure.
  • Ascend in the anterolateral pathway
  • The majority terminate in :
  1. Reticular nuclei of medulla, pons and mesencephalon
  2. Tectal area of mesencephalon
  3. Periaqueductal grey region
  • Only 10-25% reach thalamus

Thalamic Termination

Intralaminar and ventrolateral nuclei (medial nuclear group) and into certain portions of hypothalamus and other basal regions of brain

Third Order Neurons

Arise from medial nuclear group in thalamus and project to various cortical areas including limbic cortex

Localization Capability

Poor; pain localized to major body parts such as arm or leg (Option B), not specific point on arm or leg (Option A,C and D ruled out)

Neurotransmitters
  • Glutamate (fast, short-lived)
  • Substance P (slow, prolonged)

Special Features
  • Keeps person awake via reticular formation projection
  • Evokes emotional experience of pain via limbic system connections
  • Mediates autonomic responses via hypothalamic connections
  • Affects arousal, emotional, and autonomic responses of pain

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the neospinothalamic tract for pain:

choices.text: It primarily carries slow pain sensations
The first-order neurons terminate mainly in lamina II of the dorsal horn
The neurotransmitter released by the Aδ fiber is glutamate
All fibers terminate exclusively in the reticular formation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The neurotransmitter released by the Aδ fiber is glutamate

 

Explanation:

Glutamate is the primary neurotransmitter at Aδ fiber endings.

 

Neo-Spinothalamic Pathway :

Aspect

Description

Fiber Type

Aδ (A-delta) fibers

Function

Carries fast pain sensations, primarily mechanical and acute thermal pain (Option A ruled out)

First-Order Neurons

Terminate mainly in lamina I of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Option B ruled out)

Second-Order Neurons
  • Cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord through the anterior commissure.
  • Ascend in the anterolateral pathway.
  • The fibers terminate mainly in the ventrobasal complex, and a few fibers also terminate in the posterior nuclear complex of the thalamus.
  • Sparse projections to midbrain reticular formation, periaqueductal grey and hypothalamus (Option D ruled out)

Third-Order Neurons
  • Originate from specific thalamic nuclei.
  • The signals are then transmitted to other basal areas of the brain as well as somatosensory cortex

Localization of Pain
  • Fast pain is better localised than slow-chronic pain.
  • Exact localisation requires simultaneous stimulation of tactile receptors

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate (primary neurotransmitter at Aδ fiber endings) (Option C)

Topographic Organization

In spinal cord:

  • Lower body fibers placed laterally
  • Upper body fibers placed medially
  • Sacral segment fibers occupy most lateral part
  • Cervical segment fibers occupy most medial part

 

Special Features

Pain perception persists despite removing somatic sensory areas of the cerebral cortex, indicating that the brain stem, thalamus, and lower centers handle this function. The cortex only helps in interpreting pain quality, not perception.

questions.text: A patient reports severe pain when lightly touched with a cotton swab. This symptom is most consistent with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allodynia

 

Explanation: Allodynia refers to an excessive response to mild or normally innocuous stimuli. Example: Painful sensation from a light touch which is never painful.

 

Criteria

Hyperalgesia (Option B ruled out)

Allodynia (Option A)

Definition

Exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus
 

Excessive response to mild or normally innocuous stimulus

Sensitivity

Both increases sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers

Cause
  1. Primary hyperalgesia: Excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors.
    Eg : Extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin (results from sensitization of pain receptors due to local tissue products like histamine, prostaglandins)
     
  2. Secondary hyperalgesia: It is the facilitation of sensory transmission .
    Eg: Lesions in the spinal cord or thalamus

The exact cause is unknown. Likely involves error in neuronal conduction.

Eg: Painful sensation from a light touch which is never painful

Association

Both types of pain is seen in neuropathic pain and causalgia

 

Analgesia (Option C) refers to the complete loss of pain sensation. It may not be associated with the loss of other sensations. 

 

Hypoalgesia (Option D) refers to decreased sensitivity and raised threshold to painful stimuli.

questions.text: A 40 years old woman comes to the clinic complaining of severe, burning pain in her right hand following a chemical spill causing tissue damage at her workplace. Which of the following substances is responsible for her pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bradykinin

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient most likely has a chemical burn. Bradykinin is involved in mediating the chemical nociceptive stimuli experienced by the patient.

 

Chemical Nociceptive stimuli

  • Both TRPA1 and TRPV1 detects chemical stimuli
  • Bradykinin (most painful chemical stimuli)- B1 & B2 receptors (Option D)
  • Bradykinin is a potent inflammatory mediator that is released during tissue injury and contributes significantly to the sensation of pain
  • Chemical burns can cause the release of bradykinin and other inflammatory mediators, which activate pain pathways.

 

Other chemical mediators:

  • Serotonin- 5HT receptors
  • Histamine- H3/H4 receptors
  • Nerve endings also have Acid-Sensing Ion Channel (ASIC) receptors that detect H+ and cause acid induced pain.

 

Dopamine (Option A) is involved in motor pathway and not sensory 

 

Acetylcholine (Option B) is primarily involved in neuromuscular transmission and autonomic nervous system function 

 

Serotonin (Option C) is involved in the pain pathway, but is not the primary mediator in chemical nociceptive stimuli

questions.text: The TRPA1 receptors are activated by all of the following nociceptive stimuli except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heat

 

Explanation:

Transient Receptor Potential Ankyrin 1 (TRPA1) is activated by mechanical, cold and chemical stimuli.

 

Types of nociceptive stimuli and their receptors:

  • Nociceptors can be activated by mechanical, chemical or thermal stimuli.


 

Mechanical Nociceptors:

  • Respond to strong pressure (eg: from sharp objects)
  • The receptors for mechanical stimuli at free nerve ending include:Transient Receptor Potential Ankyrin 1 (TRPA1) (also for cold and chemical stimuli) (Option A, C & D ruled out)
  • Mechanical stimuli can also release ATP, which acts on purinergic receptors such as P2X and P2Y and cause pain

Thermal Nociceptors:

Cold detection:

  • TRP Ankyrin 1 - It is sensitive when the temperature is < 17°C and
  • TRP Melastatin 8 - It is sensitive when the temperature is between 8-28°C.

Heat detection:

  • TRP Vanilloid 1(also detects acid and chemicals) (Option B ruled out) - Activated when temperature is > 43°C, H+ ions and capsaicin (the active ingredient of chili).
  • TRPV2/V3/V4 - It is activated when temperature is > 52°C.

Chemical Nociceptors:

  • Both TRPA1 and TRPV1 detects chemical stimuli
  • Nerve endings also have Acid-Sensing Ion Channel (ASIC) receptors that detect H+ and cause acid induced pain
  • Bradykinin (most painful chemical stimuli)- B1 & B2 receptors
  • Serotonin- 5HT receptors
  • Histamine- H3/H4 receptors

questions.text: Nociceptors have their cell bodies located in which of the following structures?

choices.text: Ventral horn of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dorsal root ganglion

 

Explanation:

  • Nociceptors arise from cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion that send one axon to the periphery and another to the spinal cord or brainstem.
  • Nociceptors (pain receptors) are basically the free nerve endings that detect pain sensations.
  • Location of nociceptors: Arise from cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion that send one axon to the periphery and another to the spinal cord or brainstem (Option A).
  • Nociceptors activate Transient receptor potential (TRP) channels on nerve endings, which causes the neurons to depolarize and generate action potentials.

 

Ventral horn of the spinal cord (Option B) contains motor neuron cell bodies.


 

Lateral geniculate nucleus (Option C) is part of the thalamus and is involved in visual processing.

 

Sympathetic ganglion (Option D) is part of the autonomic nervous system and does not contain the cell bodies of nociceptors .

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily involved in fast pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glutamate

 

Explanation:

Nociceptors:

  • These are responsible for detection of pain.
  • These receptors are basically free nerve endings.
  • There are two types of pain:

 

 

Fast pain (First Pain)

Slow pain (Second Pain)

Fiber Type

Aδ fiber

  • Myelinated
  • Large diameter (2-5 µm)

C fiber

  • Unmyelinated
  • Smaller diameter (0.4 - 1.2 µm)

Location

Body surface

Deeper tissues

Conduction velocity

Very rapid (~12- 35 m/s)

Very slow (~ 0.5 - 2 m/s)

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate (Option B)

Substance P (Option A Ruled out)

Description

  • Rapid response
  • Mediates the discriminative aspects of pain (localisation and intensity)

Delayed, dull, intense, diffuse and unpleasant feeling associated with noxious stimulus

questions.text: Which type of receptor is known for its rapid adaptation to stimuli, making it particularly effective at detecting vibrations and rapid changes in pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pacinian corpuscles

 

Explanation: Pacinian receptors are rapidly adapting receptors sensitive to vibrations and rapid pressure changes

 

Adaptation of receptors:

  • One of the most important characteristics of sensory receptors is that they can adapt partially or completely to any constant stimulus after a period of time.
  • When a continuous stimulus is applied to a receptor, the initial response occurs at a high impulse rate, then at a progressively slower rate, which ultimately decreases to very few or none at all.

 

Mechanism:

  • Adaptation occurs in 2 ways:

 

1

In Rapidly Adapting Receptors

  • It is a faster mechanism.
  • The receptors are viscoelastic in nature so that when a stimulus is applied to one side of the receptor, it is transmitted instantly by the viscous component to the same side of the central nerve fiber, eliciting a response
  • Within a few seconds, the fluid in the receptors redistributes and the response is no longer elicited

2

In Slowly Adapting Receptors

  • It is a slower mechanism called accommodation
  • This occurs directly in the nerve fiber.
  • If there is a continued stimulus, then the tip of the receptor becomes accommodated to the stimulus.
  • This occurs from the progressive inactivation of sodium channels in the nerve fiber membrane.

 

 

Rapidly adapting receptors

Pacinian, Meissner’s and hearing organ

Slow adapting receptors

Merkel’s, Ruffini’s and free nerve endings (Option A & C ruled out)

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscles (Option B) are also rapidly adapting receptors but are sensitive to light touch rather than vibrations.

questions.text: A researcher is studying various sensory receptors and their responses to different stimuli. During an experiment with pacinian corpuscle, the researcher notes that the intensity of the initial electrical response in the receptor is proportionate with the mechanical pressure applied. What is the initial graded electrical response observed in sensory receptors upon stimulus application?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Receptor potential

 

Explanation:

Receptor potential is the graded depolarizing potential in a sensory receptor in response to a stimulus. Its magnitude varies with the intensity of the stimulus.

 

Receptor Potentials

  • A receptor potential is a type of graded potential that occurs in sensory receptors. It is a local, non-propagated change in membrane potential that occurs in response to a stimulus.
  • Receptor potential is not an action potential; instead, it causes the sensory neuron to fire action potentials.
  • Once the receptor potential reaches a critical threshold, it triggers an action potential at the sensory nerve's first node of Ranvier.

Receptor Potential" data-author="NA" data-hash="7858" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="430" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4dckPzu4YYs0VLdSl2ED1744015597.png" width="500" />

Factors affecting receptor potential:

  • Proportional Response: Amplitude of receptor potential is generally proportional to stimulus intensity.
  • Nature: Non-propagated, depolarizing potential in sensory receptors.
  • Threshold: When it reaches a critical level, an action potential is generated.
  • Stimulus Intensity: Stronger stimuli lead to larger receptor potentials.

 

Mechanism of receptor potential generation in Pacinian Corpuscle

 


 

 

Pacinian Corpuscle Mechanism

Mechanical Stimulation

  • Pressure deforms lamellae surrounding sensory nerve ending.

Ion Channels

  • Deformation opens mechanically-gated ion channels, mainly sodium (Na+).

Sodium Influx

  • Rapid influx of Na+ generates the receptor potential.

Graded Response

  • Larger deformation (stronger stimulus) leads to a larger receptor potential.

Action Potential

  • If the potential reaches ~10 mV, an action potential is generated at the first Node of Ranvier.

 

sensory nerve fiber" data-author="NA" data-hash="7859" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="358" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RwU5xVtZreVvDRUsznng1744015663.png" width="500" />

Action potential (Option A) is an all-or-none electrical signal that occurs after the receptor potential reaches a threshold. 

Synaptic potential (Option C) occurs at synapses between neurons, not in sensory receptors. 

Resting potential (Option D) is the baseline electrical state of a cell when it is not stimulated.

questions.text: Which type of mechanoreceptor is primarily responsible for two-point discrimination and the ability to read Braille by detecting fine touch and texture details on the fingertips?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iggo Dome Receptor

 

Explanation:

  • Merkel discs are often grouped together in a receptor organ called touch domes, which project upward against the underside of the epithelium of the skin.
  • This upward projection causes the epithelium to protrude, forming a dome (Iggo dome receptor, named after a scientist, Iggo) and creating an extremely sensitive receptor.
  • Blind individuals rely on the fine tactile acuity (two-point discrimination) of their fingertips to read Braille, which has dots spaced 2.5 mm apart.

 

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Location

Function

Response

Merkel’s Disc

(Option C ruled out)

Underneath the epithelium of the skin
  • Detect continuous touch and pressure,
  • Transmit strong initial signal and weaker sustained signal,
  • Localise touch sensations (Two point discrimination),
  • Determine texture
  • Transmit initially a strong response but partially adapting, then a continuing weaker response that adapts slowly.
  • Extremely sensitive when grouped in a receptor organ called touch domes

Ruffini Corpuscles

(Option D ruled out)

Deeper layers of the skin and deeper internal tissues, joint capsules
  • Important for signaling continuous states of deformation of tissue such as heavy prolonged touch and pressure
  • Help to signal the degree of joint rotation

Very slow adapting, providing continuous feedback about deformation and prolonged pressure.

Free Nerve Ending (Option A ruled out)

Found everywhere in skin

Detect touch and pressure

Can detect even light contact

 

Hair End Organ (Option B) detects movement of objects on the body surface or initial contact with the body

questions.text: Which type of receptor is most likely responsible for detecting the rapid changes in pressure and vibrations in the patient's fingertips?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pacinian Corpuscles

 

Explanation:

Pacinian Corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that are particularly sensitive to rapid changes in pressure and vibrations of tissues.
 


 

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Adaptation

Pacinian Corpuscle
(Option B)

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Adapts in a few hundredths of a second

Meissner Corpuscle
(Option A ruled out)

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Non-hairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Adapts in a fraction of a second

Hair End Organ (Option C ruled out)

Nerve fiber entwined at the base of each hair

Detects :

  • Movement of objects on the body surface or
  • Initial contact with the body

Hairy skin

Adapts readily

 

Pacinian Corpuscles" data-author="NA" data-hash="7863" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" height="383" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/8UhmWxb4yJ5FYOyml55O1744016225.png" width="500" />

questions.text: A patient reports an unusual sensitivity to temperature changes, and you suspect a disorder related to thermoreceptor function. Which of the following statements accurately describes the nerve fibers involved in transmitting signals from thermoreceptors?

choices.text: Cold receptors: myelinated type C fibers
Warmth receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers
Cold receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers
Warmth receptors: myelinated type Aβ fibers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cold receptors: myelinated type Aδ fibers

 

Explanation:

Cold receptors primarily use small, myelinated type Aδ fibers to transmit signals, which conduct at a speed of approximately 20 m/sec.

Types of Thermoreceptors

Type

Location

Transmission Pathway

Speed

Cold Receptors

(Option C)

Under the skin at spots

Type Aδ fibers (myelinated), some Type C fibers (unmyelinated) (Option A ruled out)

~20 m/sec (Aδ fibers)

Warmth Receptors
(Option B&D Ruled out)

Under the skin at spots

Unmyelinated Type C fibers

0.4-2 m/sec

The body has 3 - 10 times more cold spots (lips >>fingers) than warmth spots

Nocireceptors / Pain receptors are stimulated only in extreme degrees of cold or heat and are responsible along with the cold and warmth receptors for freezing cold and burning hot sensations.

Stimulation of Thermal Receptors

Type of Nerve Fiber

Temperature Range

Cold Receptors

10-40°C (peak ~24°C)

Warmth Receptors

>30°C (fade ~49°C)

Cold Pain Fibers

Very cold temperatures

Heat Pain Fibers

Start ~45°C

Thermal Signal Pathway

  • Transmitted in parallel pathways with pain signals.
  • Signals travel in the tract of Lissauer and terminate in laminae I, II, and III of dorsal horns.
  • Processed signals by cord neurons cross to the opposite anterolateral sensory tract and terminate in both brain stem's reticular areas and the thalamus's ventrobasal complex.
  • Removal of cortical postcentral gyrus reduces, but does not eliminate, temperature distinction ability.
